utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Worst Renaissance Fair ever.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Please let it go, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It was rife with historical inaccuracies. For example, the tavern girl serving flagons of mead, now her costume was obviously Germanic, but in 1487 the Bavarian purity laws or Rhineheitsgebot severely limited the availability of mead. At best they would have had some sort of spiced wine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re nitpicking.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh-ho! Really? Well here’s another nit for you. The flagons would not have been made of polypropylene.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Renaissance fairs aren’t about historical accuracy. They’re about taking chubby girls who work at Kinko’s and lacing them up in corsets so tight their bosom jumps out and says howdy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Bosoms would not have said howdy in the fifteenth century. If anything they would have said “huzzah!”

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t care what the bosoms say, Sheldon, I just want to be part of the conversation.

utterance.speaker: Penny (arriving with a man in tow)
utterance.content: Hi guys. Looks like you’ve been to the Renaissance fair. I’m hoping.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Renaissance fair? More of a medieval slash age of enlightenment slash any excuse to wear a codpiece fair.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, fine, whatever, um, you guys, this is my friend Eric.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Eric
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, yeah, good to see you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, it’s good to see you too. We should really go.

utterance.speaker: Eric
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Penny(leaving)
utterance.content: Bye guys.

utterance.speaker: Eric (leaving, to Howard)
utterance.content: Like your hat.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks, my mom made it. Penny with a new guy, tres awkward.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It wasn’t awkward. It wasn’t fun. Besides, what’s the big deal, we dated, we stopped dating, and now we’re both moving on.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: By moving on, do you mean, she’s going out with other men and you spent the afternoon making fifteenth century soap with Wolowitz?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That was not fifteenth century soap, my God those people need to learn you can’t just put “ye olde” in front of anything and expect to get away with it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can we please just go in, my chain mail is stuck in my underwear.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re wearing modern underwear?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Relatively modern. Why, what are you wearing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I fashioned historically accurate undergarments out of linen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You went out and bought linen?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t be silly, I borrowed one of your pillow cases.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Borrowed?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know what, I’m happy that Penny’s moving on. It gives me the freedom to move on myself.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Are you saying that you’ve been holding back?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Of course. Out of respect.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, how do you explain the ten years before Penny?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Who were you respecting then?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What? I’ve dated plenty of women. There was Joyce Kim, Leslie Winkle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Notify the editors of the Oxford English Dictionary, the word plenty has been redefined to mean two.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, what about that girl last year at Comic-con?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Doesn’t count.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What happens in costume at Comic-con, stays at Comic-con.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’re only saying that because of what happened to you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What happened to you?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: N-n-n-nothing happened to me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It wasn’t your fault, Raj, he was dressed as a green Orion slave girl.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: H-h-h-how did we get on me, we were mocking Leonard for not moving on. Dude, you have totally not moved on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes I have, it’s just a matter of actually making a date with someone.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Like who?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, there’s Joyce Kim, but she defected back to North Korea so it’s a little geographically undesireable.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What about Leslie Winkle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh no.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Her research methodology is sloppy, she’s unjustifiably arrogant about loop quantum gravity, and to make matters worse she’s often mean to me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I think she’s smoking hot.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’d hit that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’d hit particulate soil on a colloidal suspension. Mud.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, I like Leslie, but she’s not interested in dating as much as using men as tools for stress release.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, so, be a tool. Go get yourself a little rebound stress release.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Technically it would only be rebound if he and Penny had actually engaged in physical intimacy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You mean like you and Richard the slave girl?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I bought him dinner and we kissed once, that was it. And he told me his name was Kimberley!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know how I know we’re not in The Matrix?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If we were, the food would be better.

utterance.speaker: Leslie (arriving)
utterance.content: Hey, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, Leslie.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Hey, dummy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello to you, insufficiently intelligent person.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Ooh, rush me to the burn unit. Hey, Leonard, do you have a second, I need to ask you something.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, sure.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to go do work that promises significant results, as opposed to what you do, which does not. Yeah, you heard me.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Wow. So, I heard your relationship with Penny crashed to the ground like blue ice falling out of an airplane lavatory.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Where did you hear that?

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Actually I read it. Wolowitz texted me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Like blue ice falling out of an airplane lavatory. Yep.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: I thought it was a pretty good one, I gave him an L-O-L. Anyway, it got me thinking, now that you’re unattached maybe we can revisit our previous attachment.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Are you suggesting another bout of stress release.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: No, I’m all done with casual sex. From now on I’m fully committed to the traditional relationship paradigm.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really, what changed?

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: It’s hard to say, I guess there’s just a time in every woman’s life when she gets tired of waking up on a strange futon with a bunch of people she doesn’t know.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I can see how that would… a bunch of people?

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Anyway, I just figure it’s time to slow things down and who better to slow things down with than you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, I’m flattered. So, how do you suggest we proceed?

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Your place, we’ll order Chinese, you’ll rent a movie, artsy but accessible, then light petting, no coitus.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sounds fun.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: I’ll leave the details up to you, I think it’s better if you assume the male role.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you, that’s very thoughtful.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Great. Call me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Great news. My mom sent me my old Nintendo 64.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Terrific.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know what this means, don’t you? Break out the Red Bull, it’s time to rock Mario old school.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I kind of have other plans tonight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But it’s Friday. Friday’s always vintage game night. Look, mom included the memory card, we can pick up where I left off in 1999 when I had pernicious anaemia.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, the thing is, someone’s coming over.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well then, no problem, I have three controllers, the more the merrier.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, it’s a date, I have a date coming over.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, well you can’t blame me for not jumping to that conclusion.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why, what’s so unusual about me having a date?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, statistically speaking…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright, alright. Well, uh, nevertheless, I have one now and I would appreciate it if you would, you know, make yourself scarce.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, I am a published theoretical physicist with two doctorates and an IQ which can’t be accurately measured by normal tests, how much scarcer could I be?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know what I mean, could you just give us a little privacy?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You want me to leave the apartment?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You mean just go someplace else and be… someplace else?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, why should I leave, this is my apartment too.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I know it is, and if science ever discovers a second member of your species and you two would like some privacy I would be more than happy to get out of your way.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well alright then.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon? What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Playing Super Mario on a poorly coded Nintendo 64 emulator.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, but why are you doing it on the stairs?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m a modern day Napoleon exiled to the Elba of the staircase because Leonard, get this, has a date.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh. Oh, well, good for him. Yeah but, why are you sitting here, why don’t you just go to a movie or something?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alone?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, why not?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What if I choke on my popcorn, who will administer the Heimlich manoeuvre.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well then don’t order popcorn.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No popcorn at the mo… listen to yourself.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well why don’t you go to a coffee shop.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t drink coffee.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: They have other things.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What do they have?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know, you know, cookies, pastries…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Pastries such as bearclaws?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, sure.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t like bearclaws.

utterance.speaker: Leslie (entering)
utterance.content: Heya Penny. Dumbass.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leslie Winkle. Of all the overrated physicists in all the labs in all the world, why does it have to be Leslie Winkle?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, they have a lot in common. I mean they’re both scientists.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh please. The only way she could make a contribution to science would be if they resume sending chimps into space.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, well I have a date too, so see ya.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Everybody has a date. Even you, Mario, going after Princess Peach. And what am I doing, I’m just enabling you.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: This is pretty good Orange Chicken.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s from Changs.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Not Chows?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, Changs.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: What happened to Chows?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It changed.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Oh. So, how many children do you think we should have? I’m sorry, that was a little abrupt.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: A little.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: I mean there are so many things to talk about before we discuss reproduction.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I sure hope so.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Besides shortness, what genetic weaknesses run in your family?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (entering)
utterance.content: I’m sorry to interrupt, batteries dying continue.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Uh, genetic weaknesses, right, um, there’s the lactose intolerance.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (preparing an extension cord)
utterance.content: Don’t forget the male pattern baldness. When his uncles sit around the dinner table they look like a half carton of eggs.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, now my uncles are bald, but my Aunt Edna is one of the hairiest women you will ever meet. So… Sweet lady. It always tickles when she hugs me. What now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I have to make pee-pee.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Listen, I’m sorry about all of Sheldon’s interruptions, he can be a bit of an eccentric.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: If by eccentric you mean passive-aggressive East Texas blowhole, I agree.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, I think tonight was a very good start.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Me too. You’re sure you’re okay postponing intercourse until our relationship is past the initial viability test?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No problem, I’m very skilled at postponing intercourse. So I guess I’ll call you and we’ll arrange another evening.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Yes. I believe protocol dictates that you wait a minimum of 18 hours before you call so I’m not repulsed by your cloying eagerness.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Again, it’s your decision, you’re the man.

utterance.speaker: Penny (voice off, ascending the stairs)
utterance.content: No, it wasn’t my cat, it was an experiment designed by this guy named Schrodinger.

utterance.speaker: Eric (appearing round corner with Penny)
utterance.content: From the Charlie Brown cartoons?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, he was some kind of scientist, let me start again. Oh, hey Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leslie.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, goodnight.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, well, goodnight.

utterance.speaker: Leslie (whispering)
utterance.content: That ain’t going to make your point. Okay, that’s enough. Call me

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right

utterance.speaker: Penny (breaking off kiss)
utterance.content: Okay, goodnight.

utterance.speaker: Eric
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Had a great time, ciao

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I am not going back to the Renaissance Fair.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon, there’s so few places I can wear my jester costume.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t care. There are far too many historical anomalies for my comfort.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, okay, how about this. You can go dressed as a Star Trek science officer exploring a planet similar to Earth in the 1500s.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You mean like Spock?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fascinating.

utterance.speaker: Leslie (arriving)
utterance.content: Hey fellow scientists. Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, why don’t we all move over there so Leslie can join us.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hmm, let’s do it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you’re having trouble deciding where to sit may I suggest one potato two potato, or as I call it the Leslie Winkle experimental methodology.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t make this hard for me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s not hard. It’s simple. You can either sit with me, your friend, colleague and roommate, or you can sit with an overrated scientist you might have sex with.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re right, it is simple.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Third floor tonight. Mixing it up? Oh. You know, I still don’t understand why you just don’t go to dinner or something.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright, let’s say I go to dinner alone. And during the meal I have to use the rest room. How do I know someone’s not touching my food?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Goodnight Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, hold on. Are you sure things can’t work out with you and Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m just wondering if you really gave it the old college try? Or in your case the old community college try?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, where is this coming from?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard is upstairs right now with my arch enemy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Your arch enemy?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, the Doctor Doom to my Mr Fantastic. The Doctor Octopus to my Spiderman. The Doctor Sivana to my Captain Marvel.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I get it, I get it, I get it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do you know, it’s amazing how many supervillains have advanced degrees. Graduate school should probably do a better job of screening those people out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, come back, you’re losing me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leslie Winkle, Penny. She belittles my research.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, sweetie, I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: She called me dumbass.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know. I heard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Given this situation, I have no choice but to withdraw my previous objections to your ill considered relationship with Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, gee, well, thankyou for that. But, um, I think for now Leonard and I are just going to stay friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, that response is unacceptable to me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, you are a smart guy, you must know…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Smart? I’d have to lose 60 IQ points to be classified as smart.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are you going to let me talk?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You must know that if Leonard and Leslie want to be together, nothing you can do is going to stop it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You continue to underestimate my abilities madam.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, let me put it this way, if you’re really Leonard’s friend you will support him no matter who he wants to be with.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait a minute, why am I doing all the giving here? If Leonard’s really my friend, why doesn’t he have to support me in my hatred of Leslie Winkle?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Because love trumps hate.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh now you’re just making stuff up.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. Goodnight Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh Mario. If only I could control everyone the way I control you. Hop, you little plumber, hop, hop, hop.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (entering)
utterance.content: When the two of you reach a natural stopping point I’d like to have a word.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If the word is pee-pee, just do it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, you are my friend. And friends support their friends, apparently. So I am withdrawing my objection to your desire to have a relationship with Leslie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I will graciously overlook the fact that she is an arrogant sub-par scientist, who actually believes loop quantum gravity better unites quantum mechanics with general relativity than does string theory. You kids have fun.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Hang on a second. Loop quantum gravity clearly offers more testable predictions than string theory.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m listening, amuse me.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Okay, well, for one thing we expect quantii space-time to manifest itself as minute differences in the speed of light for different colours.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Balderdash. Matter clearly consists of tiny strings.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Are you going to let him talk to me like that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, there is a lot of merit to both theories.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: No there isn’t, only loop quantum gravity calculates the entropy of black holes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, don’t make that noise, it’s disrespectful.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I hope so, it was a snort of derision.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: You agree with me, right, loop quantum gravity is the future of physics.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sorry Leslie, I guess I prefer my space stringy not loopy.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Well, I’m glad I found out the truth about you before this went any further.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Truth, what truth? We’re talking about untested hypotheses, uh, it’s no big deal.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: Oh, it isn’t, really? Tell me Leonard, how would we raise the children?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I guess we let them wait until they’re old enough and let them choose their own theory.

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: We can’t let them choose, Leonard, they’re children.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wait, where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Leslie
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I could have accepted our kids being genetically unable to eat ice-cream or ever get a good view of a parade, but this? This is a deal breaker.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Look on the bright side.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s the bright side?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Only nine more months to comic-con.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Captain, I’m getting an unusual reading.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s great, you guys want corn dogs?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s a temporal anomaly. Corn dogs didn’t come into existence until the first half of the twentieth century.
